translated: Birth Stories
The Book of Elevens
The Chapter on Mother’s Keeper
The Dasaratha Birth Story
“Lakkhana and Sīta, both of you,
come down into the water.
Bharata said this:
‘King Dasaratha has died.’”
“By what royal splendor
do you not grieve, though you should?
Having heard that your father has died,
this sorrow does not overcome you.”
“What is it that cannot be protected,
that Posālaka speaks so much about?
Why should a wise and intelligent person

original: attānamupatāpaye.🔽Daharā ca hi vuddhā ca,🔽ye bālā ye ca paṇḍitā;
analyzed: attānam upatāpaye  daharā ca hi vuddhā ca  ye bālāḥ ye ca
translated: torment himself?🔽Whether young or old,🔽whether foolish or wise,
whether rich or poor,

analyzed: sabbe maccu parāyaṇā  phalānam iva pakkāna
translated: all are subject to death.🔽As there is always the danger

analyzed: niccam patanataḥ bhaya  evam jātāna madcāna
translated: that ripe fruit will fall,🔽so there is always the danger
of death for those who are born.
Some are not seen in the evening
who were seen in the morning;
some are not seen in the morning
who were seen in the evening.
If, while lamenting,🔽one were to attain some goal,
then, confused, one would torment oneself,
but the discerning would not.

analyzed: kisaḥ vivaṇṇaḥ bhavati  hisa matta ana mattano
translated: He becomes lean and pale,🔽and torments himself, his very self.
The dead do not profit by it,
and the lamenting is useless.
As a burning fire is extinguished
by water,
Even so the wise man, the learned,
the intelligent, the wise man,
quickly blows away the arisen sorrow,
like the wind a tuft of cotton.
Death alone takes away the one,
and alone is one born in a family.
But the highest union
is the enjoyment of all beings.
Therefore, the wise man, the learned,
seeing this world and the next,
knowing the Dhamma, the heart and the mind,

original: Sokā mahantāpi na tāpayanti.🔽Sohaṁ dassañca bhokkhañca,
analyzed: sokā mahantā api na tāpayanti  soham dassan ca bhokkhan ca
translated: great sorrows do not torment him.🔽I will support my mother and father,
and also my relatives,
and I will protect the rest,
this is the duty of the wise man.
For ten thousand years,
and sixty hundred years,
Kambugīva, the mighty-armed,
Rāma ruled the kingdom.”
The Dasaratha Jātaka is the seventh.
